body:
## Problem

- Not easy for a UI to fully detach from the server.
- No way for users/scripts to identify the "current UI".

On master, the current behavior is:

- ctrl-z will suspend *all* clients (and raises `VimSuspend`)
- after that, you can still connect to the server with a new UI
- you can `fg` (foreground) any of the suspended UIs
- the client processes don't exit after ctrl-z, you need to terminate them manually.

## Solution

Implement a way for the user to operate on the "current UI". instead of using job control (suspend), ctrl-z fully detaches and exits the current client UI and (without interrupting the other UIs).


### Status:

- `ctrl-z` in a client detaches the UI.
    - Also works for the default "stdio child" case, not only `nvim --remote-ui` clients.
- Builtin TUI sets info in `nvim_set_client_info` including its PID (`client.attributes.pid`).

TODO:

- [x] Move the impl out of `input.c` and plumb it through as proper keymapping.
    - Should work with any UI, not just the TUI.
    - ~~Currently it works by special-casing `ctrl-z` in the TUI input stream.~~
    - Ideally, *input sent from a UI should be mapped to a channel id.*
        - Currently, specific input is not mapped, there is only the concept of a "most-recent (current) UI".
- [x] For the "tmux" use-case, where you start a regular `nvim` and later want to detach, without any special start args.
    - Always start the server in "daemon mode" on startup.
        - If the foreground process/your terminal unexpectedly disconnects, the Nvim server stays running.
        - SIGTERM on the client only exits the client, the server stays up.
    - ~~Notes on daemonizing: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/5035#issuecomment-379408935~~
- [x] Require `[count]<c-z>`. Regular `<c-z>` without `[count]` should have its old behavior.
    - ~~For `--remote-ui` clients, ctrl-z old behavior really doesn't seem useful.~~
- [ ] Change "regular suspend" to target only the "current" UI, instead of all connected UIs.
- [ ] Scripts can ask "what's the current UI?" Set `v:ui` or add a field to `nvim_list_uis()`.
- [ ] Support the normal case where `nvim` spawns the server as a child.
    - [use detach=true](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/23093#issuecomment-2337867984)?
- [ ] `nvim --connect` without args lists servers (ordered by recency)
- [ ] `nvim --reconnect` attaches to the most-recent server.
- [ ] `:connect [server]` command performs "hot swap" (attach current UI to a different server). https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/5035#issuecomment-2343537003
    - TBD: don't know how to make this work for the "stdio" case. (workaround: always start the server as a daemon instead of using stdio).
- [ ] Docs:
    - Update `:help ctrl-z`, `:suspend`, ...
    - How to map ctrl-z so that it copies `v:servername` to clipboard.
- ~~show a warning if `ctrl-z` / `:suspend` is used server-side when UIs are attached.~~

closes https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/23093
closes https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23441

comment_data.body: Why is `!!events` no longer logged? This information is much more useful than `pending_events(events)`.
It turns out, the secret to keeping the server up... is to not actively terminate it :)
`detach=true` is all that's needed to correctly detach the server. Libuv is valuable here--saves a lot of headache trying to setup a "double fork" correctly.

- Are you definitely running `./build/bin/nvim` in all the terminals (including the server)?
- Check `$NVIM_LOG_FILE`, you should see `xxx DETACHED` when you hit `ctrl-z`.
    - Check `getpid()` and look for that PID in the logs.

    - works with and without `--headless`
- terminal B: `NVIM_LOG_FILE=n.log ./build/bin/nvim --remote-ui --server ./hello.sock`
- terminal C: `NVIM_LOG_FILE=n.log ./build/bin/nvim --remote-ui --server  ./hello.sock`
- `ctrl-z` in B terminates (only) nvim B.
- `ctrl-z` in C terminates (only) nvim C.

> I tried `:call feedkeys("\<C-z>", "n")` in xterm and this works as expected. it will disconnect the client without killing the server.

Technically, that only works by accident. The "current UI" is decided based on the most recent *user input*.

> That can be wrapped in a lua function or a vim command

As long as the command is invoked by *user input*, that will work. It won't work (reliably) if a plugin sends ctrl-z based on a timer, or some other event that wasn't initiated by user input.

> I'm not sure detach makes sense if there's no `--listen` address.

Nvim always starts a server (found in `v:servername`) even without `--listen`.

After latest push, this now also works with the default "stdio" client:

```

```

Currently, this means that if user closes their terminal, the nvim server will continue as a daemon. That's a "feature", if the terminal was accidentally closed... OTOH, swapfiles already address that. I assume we'll need a way to either opt-in or opt-out.
